section_01.section_summary: Joshua Reynolds was a talented and determined individual who was born to succeed, with a rare mixture of talent, industry, and common sense. He is considered one of the greatest painters of the 18th century, and his work was influenced by his studies in Italy, where he was exposed to the masterpieces of artists such as Michelangelo, Titian, and Rubens. Reynolds' time in Italy was invaluable, and he became a skilled copyist, with one of his copies of a Rembrandt even being mistaken for an original. After returning to England, Reynolds established himself as a portrait painter of the first class, and he played a significant role in the founding of the Royal Academy. Through his work and his annual discourses to the Royal Academy, Reynolds demonstrated his mastery of technique and his ability to balance artistic rules with creative expression.

section_02.section_summary: Sir Joshua Reynolds quickly gained success as a portrait painter due to the quality of his work and the patronage he received. As his career progressed, he moved to larger studios, raised his prices, and became a prominent figure in society. Reynolds was not only a talented artist, but also a man of the world who enjoyed the company of intellectuals and artists, including Dr. Johnson, Garrick, and Burke. Despite his accomplishments, he had his flaws, including a touch of snobbery, jealousy, and vulgarity, which were somewhat refined through his associations with distinguished people. Overall, Reynolds was a complex figure, and it is more interesting to see him as a multifaceted person rather than trying to portray him as a moral exemplar.
